# Setting 1 summary graph across exponents

```{r}
# example for plotting multiple lines
df1 <- data.frame(Time = 1:10, Value1 = rnorm(10, mean = 50))
df2 <- data.frame(Time = 1:10, Value2 = rnorm(10, mean = 60))

# Combine data frames by 'Time'
combined_df <- full_join(df1, df2, by = "Time")
long_df <- pivot_longer(combined_df, cols = c("Value1", "Value2"), names_to = "Variable", values_to = "Value")

plot <- ggplot(long_df, aes(x = Time, y = Value, color = Variable)) +
  geom_line() +
  labs(title = "Multiple Line Plot from Different Data Frames", x = "Time", y = "Value") +
  theme_minimal()
print(plot)
```

```{r}
long_df_power_setting1 <- pivot_longer(combined_df_setting1, cols = c("power_0", 
                                                             "power_1_16",
                                                             'power_1_8',
                                                             'power_1_4',
                                                             'power_1_2',
                                                             'power_3_4',
                                                             'power_9_10',
                                                             'power_1'), 
                                       names_to = "Exponent", 
                                       values_to = "Power")
```


```{r}
power_plot_summary_setting1 <- ggplot(long_df_power_setting1, aes(x = a, y = Power, color = Exponent)) +
  geom_line() +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 1)) + 
  labs(title = "Simulated Power Across Different Exponents", x = "Signal Strength - Amplitude", y = "Simulated Power") +
  theme_minimal()
print(power_plot_summary_setting1)
```
